from Anchorage.

I experienced communal living many years ago, and it was a living hell. Not 
only did I have to eat all my meals at a table with asshole jocks from 
school, I was also forced into doing chores, and participating in social 
activities with those cretins. I still have nightmares about those times. 
Thankfully, my mother came to her senses, and we now live alone in privacy. 
With no more of those silly distractions, and on demand Doritos, and Code 
Red, nothing comes between me and my $3000 gaming PC any more.﻿

comments.author: highspacefox

comments.text:
+LupusAries Well I hope I did address your points. Since most people on the 
right are not as materialistic/money obsessed as people on the left the 
label I prefer is voluntarist, or just plain anarchist if you like. The 
redundant phrase "free market" flows naturally from a free society for me. 
If you leave people free they trade with each other, they don't enslave 
themselves.

So yeah, you want to label me fine. We're all different, we all have our 
own views, what's wrong with labels?

And for me private enterprise does not "work", it is good. It is moral. 
People on the left have managed to get people to follow them to this day 
while swimming in a sea of human blood, misery and poverty. How do they do 
it? By labeling themselves as the good side; or more often their opponents 
the bad side. After all what good person wants to be on the bad side?

And the most moral principle for me is the principle of non-aggression. 
Government breaks that principle and is therefore evil. People can trade 
with each other without being aggressive. If you want me to concede that 
the modern day corporation is little more than a bribe - you "pay" your 
corporate tax and we'll often look the other way to what others wouldn't 
get away with, then fine. But once again I blame the game, not the players.
comments.author: Vote Starlight Glimmer for a Brighter Future!

comments.text:
+Zoopy Joobles has a 3" Dick WcjugmRc
Ah there comes the label again.......let's smack him into a drawer called 
leftist and let's forget what he has to say.
The easy way out......

In the same way one could label you a neo-liberal/conservative/republican.
Which I'm not going to do, because I don't know you well enough.
So kindly extend me the same courtesy, will you?

If it's to tempting to buy the hitman, it's still your fault if you give 
into temptation.

For the record, I don't hate private companies, I just think that we should 
control the bad apples in the bunch and not automatically assume them to be 
blameless.
Bad apples in government and in business need to be taken care of.
We need to weed out the bad companies and bad people leading it so that 
those who are better, and not quite that lacking in morals can come forward.

Strange, seems like you're applying that binary thinking again, you must 
either love or hate private enterprise.....sorry mate, neither life nor 
humans are that simple!

Private enterprise works well, even for the benefit of a country, if it's 
not left uncontrolled.
comments.author: LupusAries

comments.text:
+LupusAries Well if you're so concerned about the guns of government being 
bought there's  very simple solution to that. If we're going to blame the 
people buying government we can damn everyone from trade union to 
environmentalists. But again I think we should blame the hitman and accept 
that while he's there it's just too tempting not to buy his guns. 

Mankind manged to live without private slavery, it was a huge leap forward 
for society. I think it's about time we dropped the form of public slavery 
called government. 

Oh and by the way I'm not praising Pinochet but thanks to the introduction 
of a little less government and a little more freedom Chile finally became 
free (freer economically than the US) and not surprisingly the wealthiest 
country in South America. Pinochet paid big time by losing his power but 
the people of Chile benefited way more that they did under socialism.

I can tell you're a leftist and there's no way I can make you see the true 
evils of government, but I may as well tell you how I feel: the people that 
murder millions are the actual bad guys, not the people that make our 
incredible modern lives possible. If you hate private companies so much 
you're welcome to stop being a hypocrite and go live in a cave.
comments.author: Vote Starlight Glimmer for a Brighter Future!

comments.text:
+Zoopy Joobles has a 3" Dick WcjugmRc No I'm not letting them off the hook. 
You're thinking I'm letting them off the hook, which is something different.
I have criticized the US government and the US Public on numerous 
occasions. 
Especially, when it comes to their, shall we say, selective memory 
concering war crimes, and their rather selective understanding of 
proportionality. 

So you claim that since some of the governments can't be bought, corruption 
has no influence?

Which governments do you think can't be bought?

What I'm criticizing you for, is letting the companies of the hook.
As the "few scandals here and there", sorry those where just a few that I 
could name of the bat, if one cares to look there are much more.
Oh and investigate a few of them...they are not the average run of the mill 
scandal. 

Oh and in the case of Halliburton there's a stinger, wasn't cheney on their 
board?

Ah yes and the most mass murder came from "communist countries", you're 
thinking Khmer Rouge, Stalin Times in Russia, and such?

Well how about Pinochet's regime in Chile, at a time which has been called 
by some cynical neo-liberals "the wonder of Chile"?
Or you know the Case of the dirty war in Argentinia?
The Paramilitaries in Colombia?
Where those communist countries?
Where the parties commiting those crimes purely communistic?

Oh and btw. a little check what is communistic country and communism?
comments.author: LupusAries

comments.text:
+LupusAries There are different governments of different types all over the 
world. Not all can be bought ("lobbied") as easily as the United States 
government, yet they miraculous stay in power. Seems like we're letting the 
hitman off the hook again here.

A few scandals from a few companies here and there. You'll do your best to 
highlight that and ignore the death toll of 20th century demicide (people 
being murdered by their own governments, not including war.) The death toll 
is so high it can't be accurately determined within error bars of 10 
million.

And since a lot of the mass murder (if not most) came from communist 
countries it's a little harder to scapegoat private companies to let 
government off the hook for its mind bogglingly cruel crimes.
comments.author: Vote Starlight Glimmer for a Brighter Future!

comments.text:
+Zoopy Joobles has a 3" Dick WcjugmRc
Ok let's break that up, if you hire a hitman both you and the hitman should 
go to jail, that is on a social level.

As for the state level, just who keeps the governments in power? Who 
lobbies massively to keep proposals from becoming law that would constrain 
the laws of the big money?
Who owns the media outlets?

And well, concerning presidents...............remember Nuremberg?
Put him on trial, and while we're at it do that to his predecessor too!
There is an international criminal court, who would give them a fair 
unbiased trial.
If we finally put government heads on trial for their misdeeds and crimes 
in office, including war crimes, we're a big step further.

I think you misunderstood what I say about corporations using 
force......what I said is not that they are constrained by it being illegal 
or moral constraints, but rather that they deem breaking that final 
barrier, of challenging the state monopoly on force, to big a risk.
What holds them back is not their morality or character, but rather the 
risk involved.

Imagine it for a second, a corporation would choose to do violence to force 
it's claims, it would be declared an enemy of all nations, and it would 
very easy to get the people in on that.

The only question would be who gets there first, the armies or the angry 
mob....in the latter case there will be a lot of dead people but the 
companie will be in shambles either way.

Oh and they would loose their convenient scapegoat for everything that goes 
wrong.....the state and the government.

And just look at several big scandals in our present and past, quite a few 
of the big companies aren't afraid of doing something illegal if it 
promises profit.
As are some of the smaller companies, like when it came to the case of the 
Bread in Victorian england, and how they dilluted flour with things like 
plaster.
For the more modern problems, take a look at Halliburton, Apple, Foxconn, 
Trafigura, Walmart, Monsanto, Chevron, two big scandals in germany, where 
companies sold meat past it's date of expiry or falsely labeling horse-meat 
as cattle, or lipobay, or Wells Fargo/JPMorgan Genuine Title, Dyncorp, etc. 
pp.

There are people who will either bend the rules until they scream for 
mercy, or outright break them if it promises them profit.
And of those we need to get rid off, as for governments, it needs to have 
as little power as necessary, and the main power should go to the people.
Which will be tough until we have educated the people enough, a goverment 
of the masses only works when the masses are informed without bias and are 
educated enough to understand the problems at hand.
The representative system right now doesn't work, as quite a few 
politicians are actively working against the wishes of their voters.
Switzerland has shown that a partially direct democracy works, even though 
we foreigners might not like all that they decide.....
And more importantly it creates a culture of openess and honesty, most of 
their big projects for example are not plagued by constant cost overruns 
and allegations of corruption.
comments.author: LupusAries

comments.text:
+LupusAries So in other words if I hire a hitman to kill somebody only I 
should go to jail? interesting how the hitman is *always* innocent, isn't 
it? Well, since we're essentially raised by the hitman in his shitty 
schools for more than a decade it's no surprise we look the other way and 
come up with easy and safe scapegoats like corporations to bitch about 
while he's launching drone strikes on weddings.

And the reason corporations don't use force is not because it's "too risky" 
but because it's *illegal*. Governments have a monopoly on force. Our 
beloved government is nothing but a legal organized crime gang and they 
don't want any competition.

comments.text:
+perolito83 it would be a lot more expensive to build and maintain separate 
buildings, as well as run roads and services to all those buildings in what 
can be a harsh environment.  anyway, if the allure of living there IS the 
environment, why would you want to impact it so heavily by suburbanizing 
it?  this approach is efficient, low impact and financially responsible.

surroundings - and with such minor responsibilities in terms of footprint, 
the least the city could do is make the town look a bit prettier.  take a 
look at google street view - there is work to be done there.
comments.author: Karl Lehtonen (karLcx)

comments.text:
+Michael Johnstone I can understand people who prefer to live in remote 
locations, such as Alaska, even deep into the wilderness. But what I don't 
understand is living inside a building like the one on this video, the 
outdoor experience must be a big part of the appeal of living in Alaska, at 
least I would think.
comments.author: perolito83

comments.text:
+perolito83 If you want to know about the indigenous people of Alaska then 
that is a completely different story. Whittier started out as a military 
port and thus a white man's town.
comments.author: Michael Johnstone

comments.text:
+perolito83 I've talked to people who've been from Whittier, but I don't 
remember why they stayed. I do know why people generally move to Alaska, 
and in particular small isolated places: Money, Military, Adventure, and 
Isolation. Moving to is much different than making a go of it. Many people 
leave after a short time (3 years is standard military duty). Several go 
and then come back and repeat. Several become "snowbirds" and winter in 
warmer climates. (You should know that there are several families who have 
lived in Alaska since the Gold Rush days are referred to as Sourdoughs.) So 
if I had to guess about Whittier I'd say that most were government 
employees working for the port authority or department of transportation. 
In the summer the population would swell as the tourists showed up. Anyone 
born in Whittier and makes it to there teen years is looking for the first 
ticket out of there.
comments.author: Michael Johnstone

comments.text:
+Michael Johnstone thanks for sharing this mate, did you meet some of the 
people that live there? are they born and raised there and that's why they 
stay or is there some other reason that makes people choose to live there?
comments.author: perolito83

comments.text:
Been to Whittier several times. And you're correct. The remodel helped a 
lot though. Way back when it looked like military housing and I found it 
quite depressing. Before the tunnel was renovated the train ferried you and 
your car to Whittier. It is a very isolated place and mostly dreary.
comments.author: Michael Johnstone

comments.text:
+perolito83
You're a funny guy, you ask a serious question and once one answers you 
seriously, you let seriousness fly out the window.....

As for your question about work, might have a look at aunty wiki:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whittier,_Alaska

It's a tourist location in the summer and it's also a harbour that is used 
for the embarkation/deembarkation of railroad cars to/from the lower 48, 
also the Denali Express starts there.
You could call it a railway junction.
http://whittieralaska.gov/2005%20update%20Whittier%20Comp%20Plan.pdf

comments.author: LupusAries

comments.text:

comments.author: perolito83

comments.text:
+perolito83 Irony Police arrest that man! :D ;)

Sorry, but it is kinda ironic that you call that looking like soviet 
russia, when the US bought Alaska from the russian Empire. ;)

Oh and no it doesn't look like soviet Russia, or the eastern block, the 
overground district heating pipes are missing! ;)

Besides the building looks way to clean........;)

Sorry been to eastern germany, then czechoslovakia, and Poland right after 
reunification, and trust me that looked a whole lot different. 
My father went there to help build up the building section of their 
cultural heritage agency on a rural district basis. 

Or if you want an idea how the eastern block looked like, well Serbia would 
be an idea, when I was there a few years ago visiting the Wojwodina. 
We were visiting a friends grandfather who is a hungarian, who moved there 
because of his wife, my friends grandmother. 

Only those who haven't actually seen what it was like, can say that this 
building/village looks like the eastern bloc. 

As for them feeling better, well the strange thing is, that when they 
tested it in europe, where the people where the happiest, the findings 
where surprising. 

They found out that the happiest people lived in Iceland and the Faroe 
islands. 

Both places are far to the north, challenging to live, if you don't respect 
your enviroment it will kill you, in the winter you see nearly no sunlight, 
sometimes there is only 2 hours from sunrise to sunset. 

And yet the people there are the happiest, not those in Italy, Spain or 
whatever usualy suspect. 
And crime is almost non-existant there. 

Why?

Well, the answer is a little unsual....because there you'll need the other 
to survive, you'll need to work together to survive, and you're thankful 
for what you've got. 
That is why they help each other, because they need their neighbours help 
the next time.
And the society can't afford to have purely selfish people in it. 

In other words, in the more temperate and rich countries people have it too 
good.
comments.author: LupusAries

comments.text:

that looks more like a bunker than a building and spend most of your time 
inside that building. What kind of industry is in this location that people 
choose to live like this?

comments.text:

comments.text:
+perolito83 of course the outsides of the building and the public areas 
look utilitarian, because they are.. any co-op looks like that they're made 
to be robust, not pretty.. it's the apartments where personalizing comes in 
to play.
comments.author: sirstrongbad

comments.text:
Good point, because as we all know, it's impossible to act in front of a 
camera...

Now seriously, great for them, but to me it looks very depressing.
comments.author: perolito83

top_comment.text: Communal Alaska Living ... all in 1 building﻿
top_comment.author: matthew rappaport

comments.text:
i think the word you're looking for is 'community', not communal.  they 
aren't sleeping in bunk beds and sharing toilets.  it's a condo 
association.  this is in no way communal living.
comments.author: Karl Lehtonen (karLcx)

comments.text: Very cool. Need to go check it out some time!
comments.author: Tim authier

top_comment.text: What's the logic behind closing the tunnel every night?﻿
top_comment.author: Chris Kratsch

comments.text:
+Abid Omar I'm guessing since this is America If you call 911 I'm sure 
they'll send a plane or helicopter right away to rescue you.
comments.author: Chris Bautista

comments.text:
+Indie Alaska maybe have times for the tunnel direction, maybe automate the 
system, maybe hire a night-shift guy... really? what if there is an 
emergency?
comments.author: Abid Omar

comments.text:
Chris, the tunnel is one-lane only and needs staff to alternate the traffic 
every 30 minutes.
comments.author: Indie Alaska

top_comment.text: Why does the tunnel close? Fear of nightly zombie outbreak?﻿
top_comment.author: Theodor Trommler

comments.text:
Probably a few reasons, but one issue is it's a one way tunnel, so it opens 
from one side on the hour and the other side on the half hour (IIRC), and 
there are personnel associated with that. In addition there is a train 
track OVERLAYING the road, so trains use the road at the same time on the 
same very road (I believe this may be the only of its type in the world). 
More than likely this could be left to machines to handle but it's probably 
an issue of security as well, cost, and lack of demand. If anything 
happened in the tunnel it would both not be known for hours, but also shut 
an entire town down.
comments.author: Dane Kantner

comments.text: White walkers.
comments.author: Zeroczar

top_comment.text:
Can someone tell me why the close the tunnel every night? Is it to keep 
security levels up?﻿
top_comment.author: Watch Ryder

comments.text: I see so the  trains have a time-slot for passage?
comments.author: Watch Ryder

comments.text:
The tunnel was originally designed for rail use only and is not wide enough 
for two lanes. It is still being used for trains as well as cars on a 
shared single lane so they have scheduled times for the flow of traffic 
into and out of town for safety.
comments.author: Travis Hedberg

top_comment.text:
in Montreal if you use tunnels connecting some buildings (in the down town 
center only) and the Metro, its possible to never go outside, you can 
potentially do all your shopping , work and live  with out coming into 
direct contact with nature. Some small group of friends tried to live with 
out ever going outside for a year or so.. they filmed the results and made 
a mini documentary about it, i remember at the time it seemed far more 
effort than any potential benefit it could produce, mostly avoiding bad 
weather﻿
top_comment.author: anlacombe

comments.text:
+BrateTebra123

Especially the ones the illegals bring over.
comments.author: mjazzguitar

comments.text:
+Karl Lehtonen
...I am suitably castigated :(
comments.author: theymusthatetesla

comments.text:
+theymusthatetesla because it's home.  and everyone isn't just like you. 
 it's time all the naysayers learned that.
comments.author: Karl Lehtonen (karLcx)

comments.text:
So let me ask you this, then....why do you LIVE in a place where the 
weather dictates to that degree?
comments.author: theymusthatetesla

comments.text: Good luck attaining all kind of illnesses
comments.author: BrateTebra123

captions.text: We are in Whittier, Alaska. I am a teacher here.
You know, Whittier is different than, say, working in the traditional bush community.
In that we are on the road, and we're fairly, we're a tourist town in the summer.
But it's...yes we all live in the same building.
And it does sound strange, but essentially it's a condo association.
And it's, you know, you get really cozy with your neighbors.
What floor do you guys need?
See you later Nathan, have a good night.
We have everything we need really. There's a post office downstairs.
There's a grocery store downstairs.
There's a little video store, that if you want to rent videos or movies,
you can go and call her, and she'll come over.
City offices are downstairs as well. So all the  city managers and everything,
and the mayor work down there.
So you really, you don't have to leave if you don't need to.
I think in a larger community, you go to school. You travel there.
Not in Whittier. You just gotta walk over, and it takes 5 minutes, if that.
Depending on the elevator, of course.
There have been times where we've had to say, our school day starts at 8:45.
If we open the school doors at 8 in the morning, or at 6 in the morning,
the minute the light's on at the school, they would be there.
I think the proximity of the building, where all live, to the school.
It's a very seamless relationship. They don't separate that it's school and home.
It's just one place to them.
I'm your neighbor. We all live in the same building, right?
Student: I live two floors under you.
Erika: I have been with the same students for 4 years now.
So I've literally had some of them since they were in 1st grade, and now they're in 4th.
And it's like a family. I don't have discipline issues,
I don't have classroom management issues. Because they know me.
It's like coming to school with mom. They call me mom have the time anyway.
My first year or two, I had such a hard time separating that I was a teacher.
And knowing sometimes what was happening in some students lives.
But I've always had the rule, that no matter what time of the day,
what time of the night, if a student knocks on my door, I will always answer it.
You are always welcome. They know that.
I've always been a teacher, and in a previous life, I've been a fitness instructor.
And my first few years here, my fitness was always my thing.
And it was just kind of a private thing I did. I would go to the school gym on Sundays,
or wait until everybody left, and work out on my own.
And I had a lot of community members asking me to teach classes.
Last year, I was convinced by just enough people asking, that I decided to try it.
And it has gone really well. And it's really well received.
It's hard to stay healthy in a town like this.
Our weather is really challenging, we don't have a fitness center or a gym,
other than the school. The school does have a full size gym, and a weight room
that's available during school hours.
But beyond that, between the extreme winds, and the rain, and the snow,
that challenges a lot of people.
And so I think it just becomes a normal thing, to not move.
And to not be healthy. And the weather is always a great excuse.
And plus we don't have to leave this building if we don't want to.
So a lot of people don't. You know, why would you?
The tunnel creates its own sort of isolation, in that it closes every night at 10:30.
So if we want to go to dinner in Anchorage, we can't usually go and do that
on a school night, because often times, and I've had this happen more than once,
you go to a movie, and you just cross your fingers that it's gonna get out
by 9:30. Because you have to make the 10:30 tunnel.
And it takes an hour to get down here from Anchorage.
And if you don't make the 10:30 tunnel, then you're sleeping in your car.
Which happens a lot.
It would be silly to say that you live a lonely life living in the building.
Because, I have friends and neighbors, and students and coworkers,
that are right down the hall. If you're having a bad day, if you're having a day
when you think, "Gosh I haven't talked to another human being for a while,"
you can just walk down the hall, or get in the elevator.
What people say when they visit Whittier.
Well first they all go, "Ugh, you all live in that same building?"
"Isn't that strange?"
And I think what people don't realize is that it's just like an apartment building.
Or it's just like a high rise condo in a large city.
So for me it's not that strange. That's where I grew up.
I grew up in a big city, everybody lived in an apartment building.
But not the entire town.

title: I Am A Whittier Teacher | INDIE ALASKA
